critique: This executive order focuses on improving the physical fitness of American youth and adults. It establishes a council to coordinate efforts across federal agencies and enlist support from various groups. There's no direct indication of a left or right ideological tilt. The order doesn't address immigration, so it's neutral on that front. It expands executive power slightly by creating a council and directing federal agencies to assist it. It promotes federal coordination, suggesting a slight shift towards federal primacy. It balances national well-being with individual fitness, without heavily emphasizing security over liberties. It could be argued that promoting physical fitness is a form of social engineering, but it's a very mild form. There is no direct economic regulation. It promotes the well-being of all Americans, so it is neutral on social inclusion.
